meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う (in this case る) sound, you know this word is a verb. One of the kanji meanings is <kanji>divide</kanji>, which makes this <vocabulary>to divide something</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to separate something</vocabulary>. Depending on the context, it can also mean <vocabulary>to share</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to classify</vocabulary>.

Be careful not to confuse this with 分かる, a similar word with a different meaning. Think of it this way: You "separate" what you care (ける) about from everything else. You want to separate those special things you care about from all the other things you don't care about.

This word starts with an お to make it more polite. Then it has the kanji <kanji>兄</kanji> which you already know. Lastly, it has さん which is an honorific to elevate people and be polite. This is basically the formal way of saying <vocabulary>older brother</vocabulary> (versus plain old 兄). It can also be used to refer to a <vocabulary>guy</vocabulary> that you don't know who has a youthful appearance.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>substitute</kanji>, and the verb 代わる means <vocabulary>to substitute for</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to take over for</vocabulary>. Use it when one player substitutes for another in sports, for example, or when someone takes over for you at work. 

代わる is usually intransitive, but sometimes it can be transitive and take a direct object. Kind of like "to take over" in English — someone can take over your shift (transitive), or just take over for you (intransitive).
This is a noun version of <kanji>think</kanji>. What is "a think"? It's a <vocabulary>thought</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>think</kanji> <kanji>way</kanji> is really the way someone thinks. That's why this word means <vocabulary>way of thinking</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
You have a <kanji>lack</kanji> of <kanji>point</kanji>s. These are things about yourself you wish were better. These are your <vocabulary>shortcoming</vocabulary>s.

The kanji means <kanji>family name</kanji> because it goes after a family name in very formal situations. So, it's really closely tied to that. Because only men got the respect back in the day, we're calling this vocab word <vocabulary>mister</vocabulary>. You can call me Mr. Koichi if you'd like, too.

Both of these kanji have to do with names. You have both <kanji>family name</kanji> and <kanji>name</kanji>. Both of those names together makes for a <vocabulary>First And Last Name</vocabulary>... a <vocabulary>full name</vocabulary> if you will.

When you have <kanji>self</kanji> <kanji>reason</kanji>, you are able to think for yourself. When you can think for yourself, you have <vocabulary>freedom</vocabulary>. Very philosophical, this vocab is.

A <kanji>reason</kanji> <kanji>reason</kanji> is a <vocabulary>reason</vocabulary>! How could it not be? Do you have a reason why it shouldn't be? I thought not.

This word means "reason" as in the reason you're studying Japanese, or the reason you're late. That's why it can also mean similar words like <vocabulary>motive</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>excuse</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are almost exactly the same. When you see this word after a number, it’s for physical <vocabulary>bill</vocabulary>s of money.

You know what 千円 is (1000 yen). So if you add a <kanji>bill</kanji> to that you get a <vocabulary>thousand yen bill</vocabulary>. That's just the little rectangular piece of money that is worth 1000 yen.
The <kanji>country</kanji> <kanji>peoples</kanji> are the people of your country. They are <vocabulary>the people</vocabulary>.
この means "this" so この辺 just means <vocabulary>this area</vocabulary>.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>attach</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to attach something</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Compared with</kanji> this, it's <kanji>outside</kanji> what you wanted. You'll have anything <vocabulary>other than</vocabulary> that.

Start <kanji>from</kanji> something and then go <kanji>above</kanji> it. Now you have "<vocabulary>no less than</vocabulary> ___," or, in other words, "___ <vocabulary>or more</vocabulary>"! 

When used with numbers, 以上 always includes the number itself, like 十人以上 (10 or more people). In non-numerical contexts, it can mean "more than" in a looser sense, like これ以上もてない (I can't carry more than this).
<kanji>From</kanji> <kanji>before</kanji>, just means <vocabulary>previously</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>before</vocabulary> now.

The kanji portion means <kanji>fault</kanji>, so you would think the verb version is "to fault." It's a little different, though. Think of it this way, if you "fault" something, you're messing up. What's a great way to mess up? By losing something. That's why this word means <vocabulary>to lose</vocabulary>. 

Pretend like you are supposed to hold on to someone's wedding ring. You make the biggest fault of all. You lose it. Ouch.

When you do something that's your <kanji>fault</kanji> and then you say "<kanji>thanks</kanji>" after you do it, that's super-duper <vocabulary>rude</vocabulary>, wouldn't you say? Imagine doing something like this and then thinking to yourself after... wow, I was really rude.

This is also often used to mean <vocabulary>excuse me</vocabulary>, typically followed by ですが or します. Occasionally, it’s also used just on its own, usually when the speaker holds a higher or equal status to the person being spoken to. This particular usage is more prevalent among older generations and is commonly associated with masculine speech.

This word looks like a verb but it's not (sorry!). It's an adverb. The kanji itself means <kanji>certain</kanji> and the vocab version means all sorts of variations on that: <vocabulary>surely</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>certainly</vocabulary>, and <vocabulary>without exception</vocabulary> to name a few.

Your future consists of <kanji>certain</kanji> <kanji>death</kanji>. How would you feel in this situation? Probably very <vocabulary>frantic</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>desperate</vocabulary>. 

Another translation for this word is simply <vocabulary>certain death</vocabulary>, though I'd rather you learn one of the first two before this one if you can.

What has <kanji>not yet</kanji> <kanji>come</kanji>? The <vocabulary>future</vocabulary>.

未来 is usually used to talk about the distant future, and it implies that the future can’t be foreseen. So you can use it to speculate about what might lie ahead, but you probably wouldn’t use it to discuss more concrete plans, goals or predictions.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Throw a "the" in there if you'd like, as well.
The <kanji>year</kanji> <kanji>end</kanji> is the <vocabulary>year end</vocabulary> aka the <vocabulary>end of the year</vocabulary>.
You know how 月 can also mean <kanji>month</kanji>? If you add 末 on there you have the "month end" aka the <vocabulary>end of the month</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>tall</kanji> <kanji>school</kanji> is for when your kids get about as tall as they're going to get. That's <vocabulary>high school</vocabulary>, when most people stop growing taller.
A <kanji>study</kanji> <kanji>school</kanji> is obviously a place where people study and learn. In English, that's simply a <vocabulary>school</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
You know that 夏 means <kanji>summer</kanji> and 休 means <kanji>rest</kanji>. What is a "summer rest" though? It's a <vocabulary>summer break</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>summer vacation</vocabulary>.
This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>weak</kanji>? It's also <vocabulary>weak</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>weak</kanji> <kanji>point</kanji> is your <vocabulary>weak point</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
When it's <kanji>one</kanji> <kanji>o'clock</kanji> it's <vocabulary>one o'clock</vocabulary>. It's time to eat lunch, or take a nap, or something.
When it's <kanji>two</kanji> <kanji>o'clock</kanji> and a <kanji>half</kanji> what time do you think it is? That would be <vocabulary>two thirty</vocabulary>.
This is a good word to know to ask for the time. <kanji>What</kanji> is the <kanji>time</kanji>? This is how you ask <vocabulary>what time</vocabulary> it is.
The <kanji>same</kanji> <kanji>time</kanji>? Okay, let's say what we think this word means at the <vocabulary>same time</vocabulary>. Whoops, I just said it, sorry.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

A <kanji>hand</kanji> <kanji>paper</kanji> is a <vocabulary>letter</vocabulary> because letters are generally written by hand on paper.

If you want a more graphic image, imagine writing a letter on your hand, and how much it would hurt to chop off your hand and send it.
When you <kanji>write down</kanji> your <kanji>day</kanji> (and do it every day) that's your <vocabulary>diary</vocabulary>.

Even though it gets <kanji>mix</kanji>ed up as it <kanji>passes through</kanji> itself, modern <vocabulary>traffic</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>transport</vocabulary> systems are pretty amazing. This word refers to traffic and transport for pedestrians, bikes, cars, buses, trains, planes... anything that gets us from A to B.

This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>tall</kanji> or <kanji>expensive</kanji>? It's the same: <vocabulary>tall</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>expensive</vocabulary>. 

Weird that this word means both of these things, yeah? Just imagine money piled up to be really tall. That money is tall because it needs to buy something expensive.
This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>strong</kanji>? It's also <vocabulary>strong</vocabulary>.
You have <kanji>strong</kanji> <kanji>power</kanji>. You are <vocabulary>strong</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>powerful</vocabulary>. Feel your <vocabulary>strength</vocabulary>.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>teach</kanji> so the verb vocab version means <vocabulary>to teach</vocabulary>. It's also used to mean <vocabulary>to tell</vocabulary> in a more general sense.
The <kanji>teach</kanji>ing <kanji>room</kanji> is just a <vocabulary>classroom</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>reason</kanji> your <kanji>heart</kanji> does what it does is all psychological. The <kanji>study</kanji> of that is <vocabulary>psychology</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>reason</kanji> the <kanji>earth</kanji> is the way it is is because of the <vocabulary>geography</vocabulary> of it. Though it may seem kind of strange that geography is bringing reason to the earth, if you think of geography as a study, then you can think about how you try to get reason through that, as well.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

A <kanji>wind</kanji> <kanji>boat</kanji>. This is a strange one for sure. You may assume this is like one of those giant balloons you can go ride around in, and you'd be partly right. Really, this word covers the general word <vocabulary>balloon</vocabulary>, though it especially has to do with the toy-style balloons (or smaller balloons). It's a little round wind ship!
The <kanji>previous</kanji> <kanji>week</kanji> was <vocabulary>last week</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>now</kanji> <kanji>week</kanji> is <vocabulary>this week</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>end</kanji> of the <kanji>week</kanji> is the <vocabulary>weekend</vocabulary>... that is, unless you work on the weekend, but we can't cater to everyone here.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
A <kanji>gold</kanji> <kanji>fish</kanji> is really just gold in color, but it's still called a <vocabulary>goldfish</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

There are many <kanji>white</kanji> <kanji>bird</kanji>s out there, for sure, but one really stands out if you ask me. That bird is the <vocabulary>swan</vocabulary>. It's big, it's white, and it's majestic.
The <kanji>yellow</kanji> <kanji>color</kanji> is just the color <vocabulary>yellow</vocabulary>.

This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>black</kanji>? It's also <vocabulary>black</vocabulary>. Special Note: The noun version of black also exists in Japanese. It is just 黒 with the same pronunciation, but minus the い which makes it adjective-tastic.
A <kanji>black</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji> is simply a <vocabulary>Black person</vocabulary>, kind of like how a 白人 is a "White person," but a different  color.
Something that is <kanji>person</kanji> <kanji>shape</kanji>d that isn't a person? That has to be some kind of <vocabulary>doll</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>puppet</vocabulary>.
When something is <kanji>hand</kanji> <kanji>made</kanji>, it is <vocabulary>handmade</vocabulary>!
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

After learning 北口, 西口, and 東口, it's time for round four! Yep, you guessed it, adding <kanji>south</kanji> to 口 makes this <vocabulary>south exit</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>south entrance</vocabulary>.
You know that 学生 means "student" and you know that 大学 means university/college. Combine the two and you have a <vocabulary>university student</vocabulary> / <vocabulary>college student</vocabulary>.
Your <kanji>say</kanji>ing <kanji>way</kanji> is… your <vocabulary>way of saying</vocabulary>! This refers to the words you use and how you phrase things, as well as how you say it.
If you get there <kanji>previous</kanji> to something rotating (回り), you are <vocabulary>arriving ahead</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>going ahead</vocabulary> in <vocabulary>anticipation</vocabulary>.

When something is <kanji>close</kanji> <kanji>close</kanji> (the 々 character repeats the kanji that was before it) it will happen <vocabulary>in the near future</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>soon</vocabulary>. 

This is pretty vague, and it's up to the person speaking to decide how soon <vocabulary>soon</vocabulary> is. Depending on the person and the situation, it could technically be used for anything up to a few years!
This is simply a <kanji>blue</kanji> <kanji>sky</kanji> (aka a <vocabulary>blue sky</vocabulary>!).
You know 学生 is student, so what is a <kanji>small</kanji> student? Think young. That would be an <vocabulary>Elementary School Student</vocabulary>.
This is the <kanji>way</kanji> to <kanji>make</kanji> something. This is <vocabulary>how to make</vocabulary> something. You'll see this for directions on building something.

You've seen 学生 (means student). Now let's look at a student who's in the middle. Perhaps we can call this a <vocabulary>middle school student</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>junior high school student</vocabulary>, depending on where you're from.

You already know 人気 which means "popular." And you also know that 不 means "not." So what do you get when you combine the two? Something that's <vocabulary>not popular</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>unpopular</vocabulary>.
It's a <kanji>reflect</kanji>ion of an <kanji>image</kanji> on a screen, and the image is moving! What is this? It's a <vocabulary>movie</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>reason</kanji>ing of your <kanji>heart</kanji> decides what you do. Probably when kanji was being made people thought that the heart directed our actions, not our brains. So, if you think about it that way, the reasoning of your heart is your <vocabulary>mental state</vocabulary>. Nowadays that's known as <vocabulary>psychology</vocabulary>.
If you <kanji>cut</kanji> and <kanji>take</kanji> something, you are going to cut it right off. So, this verb is <vocabulary>to cut off</vocabulary>.

To <kanji>take</kanji> something and then <kanji>remove</kanji> it, is when you reach in and grab something and choose it and pull it out. This is <vocabulary>to pick out</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to take out</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
You have a <kanji>period</kanji> of <kanji>time</kanji> and it's called a <vocabulary>period</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>era</vocabulary>! Simple!

本当 is <kanji>reality</kanji> or <kanji>truth</kanji> (level 5 vocab). If you add on に, this changes the word to an adverb, and we get <vocabulary>really</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>truly</vocabulary>. 本当に!

Not to be confused with 会社, which is a company, this is <vocabulary>society</vocabulary>. When a <kanji>company</kanji> <kanji>meet</kanji>s together, it's like a bunch of people, who are in groups, who come together to live in one world. That is a <vocabulary>society</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>bright</kanji> <kanji>day</kanji> isn't today (because today was terrible), it's <vocabulary>tomorrow</vocabulary>, because you can always look to tomorrow to be a better, brighter day.

A <kanji>street</kanji> you can see with your <kanji>eye</kanji> isn't soooo big you can't see it (like a town would be), but it's still pretty big because it has a street. This section of the town is the <vocabulary>district of a town</vocabulary>, or a <vocabulary>city block</vocabulary> (though specifically one of an irregular size).
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
If there's a number before 時, it means <vocabulary>o'clock</vocabulary>. For example １時 is 1:00, and ２３時 is 23:00 or 11pm.

This is the adverb version of the kanji <kanji>big</kanji>. It's a little thing you can put in front of things to say that they are "<vocabulary>in a big way</vocabulary>" or "<vocabulary>on a grand scale</vocabulary>."
This is the noun version of the kanji <kanji>near</kanji>. So it also means <vocabulary>near</vocabulary>, or in the <vocabulary>neighborhood</vocabulary> of something.

A <kanji>machine</kanji> that pumps <kanji>wind</kanji> can malfunction and make too much, causing a <vocabulary>typhoon</vocabulary>. It's a really powerful machine to be able to move that much wind.
A <kanji>boat</kanji>'s <kanji>body</kanji> is called the <vocabulary>hull</vocabulary>.

This is a counter that can be used after numbers to let you know what <kanji>number</kanji> <kanji>room</kanji> it is. It's a <vocabulary>room number</vocabulary> that you use in apartments and hotels to know exactly which room you're looking for.

The <kanji>big</kanji> <kanji>sky</kanji> isn't just any old patch of sky. It's <vocabulary>the skies</vocabulary> above — <vocabulary>the open sky</vocabulary> where birds soar, <vocabulary>the heavens</vocabulary> where stars twinkle.

You already learned 空 for "sky," right? 大空 basically means the same thing, but with a more poetic sense of grandeur and scale. You won't hear it much in everyday conversation, but you'll encounter it in things like literature, song lyrics, and slogans or taglines for aviation-related media.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. 

見当たる is made up of the kanji for  <kanji>see</kanji> and <kanji>right</kanji>, so what happens when you see the right thing? It was able <vocabulary>to be found</vocabulary>! 

This word is generally used in the negative form (見当たらない). You can use it as a roundabout expression for when you can’t find what you’re looking for.
You already learned that 三角 means "triangle." Well this means <vocabulary>triangle</vocabulary> too, but it's the mathematical term. You should use it in math class.
You know that 活用 means "conjugation" and that 〜形 means "form," so that means this is the <vocabulary>conjugated form</vocabulary>!

Okay, so this one is really weird, sorry. Each of us only get <kanji>one</kanji> <kanji>body</kanji> in our lifetimes, right? Well what <vocabulary>the heck</vocabulary>! What if I want more than one body. Let's all be mad about this together.
A <kanji>small</kanji> <kanji>voice</kanji> is so small that you can hardly hear it. It's a <vocabulary>low voice</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>whisper</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>ocean</kanji> <kanji>king</kanji>'s <kanji>star</kanji> is <vocabulary>Neptune</vocabulary>! If you know anything about Roman mythology this should be easy to remember!

Start <kanji>from</kanji> something and then go <kanji>below</kanji> it. Now you have "<vocabulary>no more than</vocabulary> ___," or, in other words, "___ <vocabulary>or less</vocabulary>!"

When used with numbers, 以下 always includes the number itself, like 十人以下 (ten or fewer people). In non-numerical contexts, it can mean "less than" in a looser sense, like お前は犬以下だ (You're less than a dog).
<kanji>Town</kanji> <kanji>peoples</kanji> are the <vocabulary>townspeople</vocabulary>! This can also be singular, so a <vocabulary>townsperson</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>next</kanji> <kanji>week</kanji> is the <vocabulary>next week</vocabulary>. It isn't last week or this week, it's the next one!

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>light</kanji> or <kanji>shine</kanji>, so the verb is <vocabulary>to shine</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to flash</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to glitter</vocabulary>. Just imagine what happens when something emits light!
<kanji>From</kanji> <kanji>after</kanji>, just means <vocabulary>after this</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>from now on</vocabulary>.
<kanji>One</kanji> <kanji>bread loaf counter</kanji> is counting <vocabulary>one loaf of bread</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Two</kanji> <kanji>bread loaf counter</kanji>s are counting <vocabulary>two loaves of bread</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>fire</kanji> <kanji>star</kanji> is <vocabulary>Mars</vocabulary>. This should be easy to remember, because Mars is the only planet in our solar system that's the color of fire.

The <kanji>tree</kanji> <kanji>star</kanji> is the planet <vocabulary>Jupiter</vocabulary>. Imagine Jupiter covered in very strange trees — the kind that are able to take root in gas! It's a pretty weird image, but will hopefully help you to remember this word. Alternatively, think about how the clouds around Jupiter make patterns that look a lot like wood grain.

A <kanji>person</kanji>'s <kanji>hometown</kanji> is a <vocabulary>human habitation</vocabulary>, or a <vocabulary>village</vocabulary>. This word has a slightly old-fashioned feel, and it's usually used for small villages in the countryside.

It's often combined with はなれた (separated) to talk about how far away from the nearest human habitation something is.

What's <kanji>part</kanji> of an hour? A <vocabulary>minute</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>minutes</vocabulary>! This word is the suffix version of 分, so it goes after numbers to say how many minutes, and is used for telling the time too.
Your <kanji>inside</kanji> ポケット is your <vocabulary>inside pocket</vocabulary>.

Adding "third generation" to someone's name means that they are the third generation of people with that name. In this case, the person's name is ナポレオン (Napoleon), so this means <vocabulary>Napoleon The Third</vocabulary>, also written as <vocabulary>Napoleon III</vocabulary>.

You <kanji>correct</kanji> the <kanji>moon</kanji> because it's a <vocabulary>New Year</vocabulary>. It's the beginning of a fresh year, so you gotta have the moon in the correct position.

正月 usually refers to the first few days of a new year, and it's one of the biggest holidays in Japan. Originally, it meant the entire first month of the new year, so you still might see it used that way in some contexts — especially historical ones.

<kanji>Doing</kanji> something as a <kanji>group</kanji> requires a <vocabulary>system</vocabulary>. Without some sort of <vocabulary>structure</vocabulary>, everyone does their own thing, and you would never be able to get stuff done as a group, you know?

仕組み refers to the concept of a "mechanism" or "system." It includes the underlying structure, organization, or framework that governs how something works or operates, highlighting its logic, order, and other often unseen things.

You've got a <kanji>sea</kanji> <kanji>water</kanji> <kanji>fish</kanji>, or in other words, a <vocabulary>saltwater fish</vocabulary>.

海水魚 refers to fish that live in the ocean, as opposed to freshwater fish.

Go <kanji>north</kanji> into the <kanji>country</kanji>. Now you're in <vocabulary>northern country</vocabulary>.

北国 is used to describe northern regions where it gets all cold and snowy in winter, like Hokkaido or Tohoku in Japan or parts of Finland or Canada outside of Japan.

The <kanji>west</kanji> <kanji>sun</kanji> is, of course, the <vocabulary>afternoon sun</vocabulary>. 

西日 describes the sun when it's in the western part of the sky. It generally refers to the afternoon sun, but it can also mean the <vocabulary>setting sun</vocabulary> or the <vocabulary>evening sun</vocabulary>. Basically, you can use it for sun or sunlight from mid-afternoon until sunset!
You have the kanji for <kanji>east</kanji> combined with アジア, the word for "Asia" — that makes this <vocabulary>East Asia</vocabulary>. Can you name all the countries in 東アジア?

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>bright</kanji>, but the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to dawn</vocabulary>. It gets bright each morning when a new day dawns, so the connection kinda makes sense, right?

While 明ける is commonly used with 夜 to talk about the dawn breaking, it's also often used to talk about other time-related transitions. Because of this, it can mean <vocabulary>to end</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to begin</vocabulary> depending on the situation, as in 冬休みが明ける (winter vacation ends) or 年が明ける (the new year begins). Think of it like a new phase in your life is "dawning."
